body:
这不是一个项目,你应该把issue提到这个项目
https://github.com/alibaba/druid

The main reason why I put ParseHandler in api is to store meta data that might be necessary information. I inspired this structure from hive meta data class(org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.metadata.HiveStorageHandler). I though that might be more information that could be able to used for running other transforming job. but I fully agree with what you're worried about. so you mean, some type of extend class of MapInputRowParser should be moved to indexing-hadoop module? Is it okay to change the module location and re-apply for PR if I understand it correctly?
WORKS LIKE A CHARM!!!!!!!!! :* :* :* :*

IMHO the longer term solution is to make the coordinator load logic a bit smarter, and have the segment cache space represent the maximum total on disk size you are willing to let druid segments consume, even during it's age out period for dropped segments.

[Himanshu] I think that already happens .. to-be-deleted segments are counted against maxSize config in SegmentLocation till they are actually deleted from disk. But, they are not counted against `druid.server.maxSize` which would be a major change at coordinator side.
This is done, there is a finalizingFieldAccess post-aggregator now.
@drcrallen do you agree with this?
@gianm do you have more comments on this PR?
started reviewing this PR, some explanatory javadocs on `NewestSegmentFirstIterator` class would be helpful.
is this feature general enough that any druid user can just turn it on and forget about it? if not, then can you please add some blurb to the docs explaining when it should be enabled and when not.

@jihoonson @gianm 

Thanks for the reviews, I addressed the comments and added the following features:
- Disk snapshots of the caches, these will be used during initialization if a service cannot sync with the coordinator
- A "refresh all" cache syncing API on the coordinator
- loadStatus API (I also added "/db/" to some of the API paths to prevent path conflicts")
@leventov  @gianm  updated the PR based on your comments, please check again.

I was able to get it working by doing the following:
- Add hortonworks maven repository http://repo.hortonworks.com/content/repositories/releases
- Add spring.io maven repository  http://repo.spring.io/plugins-release
- Set `hadoop.compile.version` to: `2.7.3.2.5.3.0-37`
- Had to disable module `druid-kerberos`
- Built the distro and there were no more runtime version incompatibility: 

Following error was gone:
```
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.TransferManager.<init>(Lcom/amazonaws/services/s3/AmazonS3;Ljava/util/concurrent/ThreadPoolExecutor;)V
        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.s3a.S3AFileSystem.initialize(S3AFileSystem.java:287) ~[?:?]
        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.createFileSystem(FileSystem.java:2669) ~[?:?]
        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.access$200(FileSystem.java:94) ~[?:?]
        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem$Cache.getInternal(FileSystem.java:2703) ~[?:?]
        at org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem$Cache.get(FileSystem.java:2685) ~[?:?]
```

The code change can be seen here - https://github.com/amalakar/druid/pull/1/files

@yaochitc 

Sounds great! Your approach is the same as what I'm thinking. Is your work open publicly? Or would you please suggest some start points?

Currently, I'm testing [Druid Hadoop Inputformat](https://github.com/implydata/druid-hadoop-inputformat). But not sure it provides high read-throughput and uses inverted index.

Thanks.
+1 after ci.

@himanshug thank you for the review. I added more documents to explain when the automatic compaction is useful (https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5102/files#diff-fd047eb9f74cdf2a732aa0d3f72772feR341, https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5102/files#diff-745f7bb3fc90d4a31c1658733f19159cR339, https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5102/files#diff-507910e969a3afeceb1f9dbe9be0a644R138) and added javadocs to NewestSegmentFirstIterator.
not a critical bug though as most of the time, there are no missingSegments .

Hi @amalakar, it seems like this is due to Parquet's parquet-to-avro converter (which Druid uses for reading Parquet files) not supporting int96. I'm not sure what the best fix is. Maybe upgrading parquet would help if it's been fixed in a newer version. Or maybe using a Parquet reading strategy that doesn't involve conversion to Avro. If you're familiar enough with Parquet to help contribute the latter, you could give that a shot.
@leventov LGTM; sorry, am a few days behind on github email at the moment.
LGTM
@drcrallen raised #5154

Looks like it is not fixed in newer parquet - https://github.com/apache/parquet-mr/blob/master/parquet-avro/src/main/java/org/apache/parquet/avro/AvroSchemaConverter.java#L279

The parquet-avro repo also seems to have no commit in last one year. Getting rid of the avro converter in the druid parquet extension looks like the right path to me. I will probably take a stab, but I  am very new to druid so not familiar with code base and interfaces. Also I will probably get to it only early next year.

@jon-wei please include some comments in the `.travis.yml` file about why those settings are being used (link to this issue?) since probably, at some point in the future, the "deprecated" image will be removed and we'll have to figure out what's going on.
@gianm Added comments
Cool! The endpoint configuration should be trivial with the new AWSClient-builder thingy. That just needs to be propagated trough-out the stack.

I just had the same issue:
- Druid 0.9.2
- Lookup DimensionSpec in nested GroupBy
- GroupByStrategy V2
- Lookup was configured with `lookups-cached-global` and is read from CSV from HDFS

I noticed that this was my only Lookup which had `injective: true`. As soon as I changed it to `false` everything was fine again.

If you run [this](https://gist.github.com/gianm/97c08f7910cae1a08bec4e1cbae509a3) test from @gianm it will succeed. If you then change  the parameter for `MapLookupExtractor.isOneToOne` to `true` (which means injective afaik) then the test fails. It should succeed in both cases in my opinion.

I had no chance to test this in newer Druid versions yet.

Hi

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3073892/33953249-a776ea76-e034-11e7-9639-366b5403c165.png)

I think that this bug is fixed. I have tested, and the column duration it is not more 0
@drcrallen @himanshug Could you please review the latest changes?
Please review @gianm . Want to get to an agreement on high level approach and i can go ahead and fix rest of the syntactic issues. thanks.
@jon-wei thanks for the quick update! +1 after CI.
@jihoonson thanks for the review!
@yuppie-flu I guess the IP address is wrong. Would you check it again? If you're using Ubuntu, localhost might be 127.0.1.1. Also, please try ```export DOCKER_IP=$(docker-machine ip integration)```.

@jihoonson I'm using Archlinux and pretty sure that localhost is 127.0.0.1
```
[kozlov@glenovo ~]$ cat /etc/hosts | grep localhost
127.0.0.1	localhost.localdomain	localhost
```
I did `export DOCKER_IP=127.0.0.1`. I can not execute the above command, cause I do not have `docker-machine` command. This tool is only for MacOS and Windows afaik.

@yuppie-flu then, container's IP address is probably ```172.17.0.1```. Would you check it? If the integration test fails, you can see the containers are still running instead of being stopped on failures. Then, you can get the IP address via several ways like ```docker inspect```.

BTW, docker machine is also available for linux. Please check out https://docs.docker.com/machine/install-machine/.
`SchemalessTestSimpleTest.testFullOnTopN()` needs to be re-enabled maybe
Still testing in the cluster.

Removing the "timestamp" column fixed the issue.

http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/lookups-cached-global.html#jdbc-lookup
> The JDBC lookups will poll a database to populate its local cache. If the tsColumn is set it must be able to accept comparisons in the format '2015-01-01 00:00:00'. For example, the following must be valid sql for the table SELECT * FROM some_lookup_table WHERE timestamp_column > '2015-01-01 00:00:00'. If tsColumn is set, the caching service will attempt to only poll values that were written after the last sync. If tsColumn is not set, the entire table is pulled every time.
Hi @mohanrajnaidu, thank you for the report. It's a bug in 0.10.1 and will be fixed in 0.11.0. Please see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4948.
Labelling `Design Review` because this PR introduces a new `@ExtensionPoint`.
@a2l007 :+1:, thanks!
@palanieppan-m I'll review this shortly, thanks for putting up the patch
Please merge master into your branch.
@leventov done
Also look into https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/5169 before enabling it by default.
@gianm can you color this with a couple of use cases that highlight the need for optimization?
@clintropolis could you please also give this PR a title that looks more sensible in git commit history.
@jihoonson please let me know when you're done with this, I'm assuming https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5149 needs to be merged first to complete this PR.
@gianm I'm fine to merge this without a test
Can we merge this?
@himanshug thanks. I'll let you know when it's ready.

> I also believe that #5161 is exacerbated by this patch (as it makes it possible to reissue a previously-pending segment identifier, which could cause a similar issue to the race from #5161). But I think that's fine, since the fix to #5161 should involve overwriting, which would fix both problems.

@gianm Good point. I agree.

I think it should be precomputed for column and stored along with the column, if such optimization makes sense for a column. Along with min, max, average for columns, and other types of O(1) information that could be useful during querying. It should be accounted here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/projects/1

@himanshug I fixed this issue here for `0.10.1`: https://github.com/Plumbr/druid/commit/640277f00861cbcd2500477703bba54f3e114e9d. We have by now successfully reindexed some months' worth of data with a version built from that branch. However, porting the fix to `master` is non-trivial because `io.druid.indexer.hadoop.DatasourceInputFormat` was changed in newer versions. We also don't have a `0.11` cluster at hand to verify the fix. Is it possible to merge the fix at least for `0.10`?
does this set limit for request headers only for for headers sent by Druid in the response too ?
LGTM overall.

No, this does not increase the limit size on the response. Do you think we need to make that too configurable ? 

[Himanshu] No, I think this PR is fine. I was just curious if the changes in this patch did that as well, not something that needs to be done here.
@leventov can you please add the motivation of this PR?

@gvsmirnov In Druid code dev workflow, bugs are always fixed in master and then backported into specific release branch if necessary. we wouldn't be able to do a new druid release of 0.10.1 even if we merged it in 0.10.1 and it would be weird for a bug to be fixed in an older unreleased branch but not in master and upcoming releases.
@b-slim I don't know what to add to the PR description, this is the motivation.
@leventov it can be as simple as `since it is deprecated and unused`....
LGTM, can you fix the CI errors?

@leventov handled comments.

For the BaseNullableColumnValueSelector method isNull() returning boolean value, I still feel that returning a boolean instead of three-valued logic is cleaner api wise.  
To address your review comment, I have changed BaseObjectColumnValueSelector to not inherit isNull(). boolean isNull() is only meant for Long/Float/Double selectors where the return type is primitive value instead of Object. For the selectors to be used as ObjectSelectors the user should call getObject() which returns a Nullable object.

Now for the MapVirtualColumnValueSelector case that you pointed out, modified isNull() method to return always false, since it is not supposed to used as a Long/Float/Double column selector. We can also throw Unsupported Ex there, but chose to return false as the implementations for Double/getFloat/getLong also return 0 always instead of unsupported ex.

It feels that it's going to be impossible to impelement this transparently for query engines and indexing. It should be backed in ad-hoc manner into TopN, GroupBy engines, indexing, etc, all separately.
@nishantmonu51 could you please review this?

its frequency has increased recently, I have seen it fail a couple of times.

'''
RemoteTaskRunnerTest.testStatusRemoved:315 » Timeout Timeout waiting for task.
'''
i wonder if this might be related to zk issue, bumping up version might help.
well, I'm pretty positive that it would be a curator/zookeeper issue :)
@nishantmonu51 can you add recommendation to increase header size via these configs in the kerberos module documentation ? as its likely that users of that module would hit the issue.
@himanshug Thanks for the review.  Added.

perhaps `openDruidConnection` in `DruidMeta` needs to be adjusted re: concurrency, but that requires some more thought and this PR is just meant as a quick fix to make the test stop failing
@himanshug addressed your comments. It's ready for review now.
@nishantmonu51 some style issues failing the build.
As we discussed earlier, it would be a nightmare to manage in future, if there is some changes inside metadata core classes. A lot of changes have been done in core, so I'm closing this for now.

java version "9.0.1"

I wouldn't say this is a bug. Java 9 broke compatibility (mostly unspecified features, but still) in many ways. It's a feature of a project to support both Java 8 and 9.

LGTM if zookeeper server upgrade is not required.
